webwork-tex.statement:
Which is traveling faster, a car whose velocity vector is \(30\vec i + 35\vec j\), or a car whose velocity vector is \(40\vec i\), assuming that the units are the same for both directions? \leavevmode\\\relax
\par\vtop{\def\bitem{\hbox\bgroup\indent\strut\textbullet\ \ignorespaces}\let\eitem=\egroup \bitem \text{?}\eitem \bitem \text{the first car}\eitem \bitem \text{the second car}\eitem \vskip3pt} is the faster car. \par At what speed is the faster car traveling? \leavevmode\\\relax speed = \mbox{\parbox[t]{12.5ex}{\hrulefill}}
webwork-tex.solution:
\par \par {\bf Solution: }\par SOLUTION \par
We need to calculate the length of each vector to find the speeds of the two cars: \[|| 30\vec i + 35\vec j || = \sqrt{30^2 + 35^2} = \sqrt{2125} \approx 46.098\] and \[|| 40\vec i || = \sqrt{40^2} = 40.\] So the first car is faster.
\par
